Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Novel Heme Chemistry of Cytochrome c'

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will investigate the novel heme chemistry of Alcaligenes xylosoxidans cytochrome c' (AXCP) with a particular focus on undergraduate involvement. The PI and coworkers have previously reported the unprecedented reactivity of AXCP, whereby nitric oxide (NO) coordinates to the proximal heme face by way of a putative dinitrosyl intermediate. This alternative heme-NO binding mode, involving both distal and proximal heme faces, is challenging previous assumptions of how heme proteins react with NO, and suggests novel mechanisms for modulating ligand interactions that may be relevant to heme-based sensors, such as soluble guanylate cyclase. The novel heme-NO chemistry of AXCP takes on further significance in the light of reports that cytochrome c' may protect bacteria against NO toxicity, either as an NO reductase, or else as a reversible NO-transporter. The PIs group will perform a detailed structure reactivity based dissection of the proximal and distal heme pockets using a combination of kinetics, spectroscopy, mutagenesis, high-resolution x-ray crystallography, and electrochemistry. Specific aims are to (i) understand the mechanism of proximal NO binding (ii) determine the role of the proximal and distal pockets on heme-NO release, and (iii) investigate heme redox reactivity.

The broader impacts of this project include the exceptional opportunities for undergraduate students at Eastern Oregon University (EOU)--a small, public liberal arts college--to be engaged in cutting-edge research. In addition to carrying out protein purification and kinetic measurements at EOU, students will travel to collaborating laboratories to gain additional experience in protein characterization, as well as insights into graduate research environments. Overall, the project will support the thriving undergraduate research culture at EOU (exemplified by the in-house Eastern Oregon Science Journal) and will build on the previous successes of the PI in encouraging students to pursue science at the graduate level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cytochromes c' are heme proteins found in many nitrogen-fixing, denitrifying, and photosynthetic bacteria with a proposed role in protecting against nitric oxide (NO) toxicity. They are unusual in being able to bind NO to either side of the heme: formation of a distally-bound six-coordinate heme nitrosyl (6cNO) is followed by conversion to a proximal five-coordinate heme nitrosyl (5cNO) via a dinitrosyl intermediate. Heme-NO reactivity at both heme faces (together with weak distal CO binding and the absence of an O2 complex) represents a new strategy for diatomic gas recognition in proteins that is relevant to the activation of heme-based gas sensors. In this project we performed a detailed structure-reactivity-based dissection of the proximal and distal heme pockets of Alcaligenes xylosoxidans cytochrome c'  (AXCP) using a combination of kinetics, spectroscopy, mutagenesis, high resolution X-ray crystallography, and electrochemistry. Specific aims were to (i) understand the mechanism of proximal NO binding (ii) determine the role of the proximal and distal pockets on heme-NO release, and (iii) investigate heme redox reactivity.

To shed light on the AXCP proximal heme-NO binding mechanism, activation parameters were determined for distal and proximal NO-binding reactions from the effect of temperature and hydrostatic pressure on rate constants. Our results suggested that the rate-limiting step of the distal 6cNO to proximal 5cNO conversion involves the scission of the bond between the iron and the proximal His120 ligand. We carried out structural and kinetic characterization of a range of proximal heme pocket variants involving mutation of the positively charged Arg124 (which lies adjacent to the His120 ligand). The role of Arg124 appears to be to slow down Fe-His scission due to a cation-pi interaction with the proximal His ligand, prolonging the lifetime of the distal 6cNO intermediate. Contrary to previous proposals, we found that H-bond stabilization (by residue 124) of the NO ligand is not required for proximal 5cNO formation. We also studied the effect of His rebinding to heme after dissociation of the proximal NO ligand. Flash photolysis absorption studies of native AXCP provided the first direct observation of the binding of the proximal His120 ligand to four-coordinate (4c) heme following the photolysis of the proximal 5cNO complex. We showed that the rate of rebinding of the proximal His ligand is fast enough to compete with NO rebinding from solution. Since NO exiting the AXCP proximal pocket must rebind via the distal face, the rapid reattachment of the His ligand acts as a one-way gate for releasing proximally-bound NO.

On the opposite (distal) heme face, removal of steric crowding via a Leu16Ala mutation resulted in a remarkable 6-8 orders of magnitude increase in the distal heme affinities for CO and  NO as well as an O2 affinity greater than that of myoglobin. The Leu16→Ala replacement also abolished proximal 5cNO formation, trapping NO as a distal 6cNO complex and suggesting that the distal to proximal heme-NO conversion in native AXCP is driven by distal steric constraints. A 1.25 Å resolution crystal structure of the CO-complex of native AXCP shows that CO binding is accompanied by significant distal pocket rearrangements, including rotation of Leu16 and flip of the 7-propionate from the distal to proximal heme face. By contrast, the L16A-CO complex shows no such distal pocket rearrangements (due to a larger distal pocket). Potentiometric measurements show that native-CO complex has a potential that is ~600mV higher than that of the L16A-CO complex, (corresponding to a 58 kJ mol-1 higher energy for native-CO). On the basis of the energy costs of CO-induced conformational changes in the native-CO complex we propose a “loaded spring”
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Cytochromes c' are heme proteins found in many nitrogen-fixing, denitrifying, and photosynthetic bacteria with a proposed role in protecting against nitric oxide (NO) toxicity. They are unusual in being able to bind NO to either side of the heme: formation of a distally-bound six-coordinate heme nitrosyl (6cNO) is followed by conversion to a proximal five-coordinate heme nitrosyl (5cNO) via a dinitrosyl intermediate. Heme-NO reactivity at both heme faces (together with weak distal CO binding and the absence of an O2 complex) represents a new strategy for diatomic gas recognition in proteins that is relevant to the activation of heme-based gas sensors. In this project we performed a detailed structure-reactivity-based dissection of the proximal and distal heme pockets of Alcaligenes xylosoxidans cytochrome c' (AXCP) using a combination of kinetics, spectroscopy, mutagenesis, high resolution X-ray crystallography, and electrochemistry. Specific aims were to (i) understand the mechanism of proximal NO binding (ii) determine the role of the proximal and distal pockets on heme-NO release, and (iii) investigate heme redox reactivity. To shed light on the AXCP proximal heme-NO binding mechanism, activation parameters were determined for distal and proximal NO-binding reactions from the effect of temperature and hydrostatic pressure on rate constants. Our results suggested that the rate-limiting step of the distal 6cNO to proximal 5cNO conversion involves the scission of the bond between the iron and the proximal His120 ligand. We carried out structural and kinetic characterization of a range of proximal heme pocket variants involving mutation of the positively charged Arg124 (which lies adjacent to the His120 ligand). The role of Arg124 appears to be to slow down Fe-His scission due to a cation-pi interaction with the proximal His ligand, prolonging the lifetime of the distal 6cNO intermediate. Contrary to previous proposals, we found that H-bond stabilization (by residue 124) of the NO ligand is not required for proximal 5cNO formation. We also studied the effect of His rebinding to heme after dissociation of the proximal NO ligand. Flash photolysis absorption studies of native AXCP provided the first direct observation of the binding of the proximal His120 ligand to four-coordinate (4c) heme following the photolysis of the proximal 5cNO complex. We showed that the rate of rebinding of the proximal His ligand is fast enough to compete with NO rebinding from solution. Since NO exiting the AXCP proximal pocket must rebind via the distal face, the rapid reattachment of the His ligand acts as a one-way gate for releasing proximally-bound NO. On the opposite (distal) heme face, removal of steric crowding via a Leu16Ala mutation resulted in a remarkable 6-8 orders of magnitude increase in the distal heme affinities for CO and NO as well as an O2 affinity greater than that of myoglobin. The Leu16→Ala replacement also abolished proximal 5cNO formation, trapping NO as a distal 6cNO complex and suggesting that the distal to proximal heme-NO conversion in native AXCP is driven by distal steric constraints. A 1.25 Å resolution crystal structure of the CO-complex of native AXCP shows that CO binding is accompanied by significant distal pocket rearrangements, including rotation of Leu16 and flip of the 7-propionate from the distal to proximal heme face. By contrast, the L16A-CO complex shows no such distal pocket rearrangements (due to a larger distal pocket). Potentiometric measurements show that native-CO complex has a potential that is ~600mV higher than that of the L16A-CO complex, (corresponding to a 58 kJ mol-1 higher energy for native-CO). On the basis of the energy costs of CO-induced conformational changes in the native-CO complex we propose a "loaded spring" mechanism whereby the high energy state of the native-CO complex leads to slower CO binding but faster CO release.
